A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.

A Dedekind domain is an integral domain in which the theorem on unique prime factorization holds for ideals. It is a nonzero ring without nontrivial zero divisors, and Dedekind's theorem on unique prime factorization for ideals is applicable.
The pair (S, R), where S is a subring of R, is called a ring extension.

Let $R$ and $R'$ be rings. A map $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a ring homomorphism if it satisfies two conditions: (i) $\varphi(a+b)=\varphi(a)+\varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$, making $\varphi$ a group homomorphism with respect to addition, and (ii) $\varphi(a \cdot b)=\varphi(a) \cdot \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$ and $\varphi(1)=1$, making $\varphi$ a monoid homomorphism with respect to multiplication.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.

An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.

A pair of fields $K \subset L$, where $K$ is a subfield of $L$, is called a field extension. $L$ is a field extending $K$ or an extension field of $K$, or simply that $L$ is a "field extension" of $K$.
Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field
The multiplicative group of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_q^*\]$. It is cyclic of order $q-1$.
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.
A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A group is defined as a monoid with additional properties. Therefore, the concept of a monoid must be defined to understand what a group is.
A Dedekind domain is a specific type of integral domain, so the concept of an integral domain must be defined first.
A ring homomorphism involves the concept of rings, so rings must be defined first.
The least common multiple is defined in terms of divisibility within a ring, so the concept of a ring must be defined first.
An A-module is defined as an abelian group with additional structure, so the concept of an abelian group must be defined first.
The torsion submodule is a submodule of an A-module, so the concept of an A-module must be defined first.
A field extension is a specific type of ring extension where the rings are fields, so the concept of a ring extension must be defined first.
The multiplicative group of a finite field is a group formed by elements of a finite field, so the concept of a group must be defined first.
A separable extension is a specific type of field extension, so the concept of a field extension must be defined first.
A transposition is a specific type of permutation, which is a concept within group theory, so the concept of a group must be defined first.
A subset is a fundamental concept in set theory, which is a prerequisite for understanding all other mathematical structures.
